projects.name: Black Jack
projects.desc: A command-line blackjack game built with Python-3 that allows players to place bets, make decisions on their hands, and compete against the computer, using traditional blackjack rules and gameplay mechanics.
Features: Standard 52-card deck
Ability to place bets and adjust wagers
Player can hit, stand, or double down
Dealer follows traditional blackjack rules
Game ends when either the player or dealer busts, or the player chooses to stand and the dealer finishes their turn

projects.name: Netflix Recap
projects.desc: Netflix Recap is a data analysis project designed to help you better understand your viewing habits on the popular streaming platform. By analyzing your Netflix watch history, the project provides valuable insights such as your most watched series, your most watched genre, and how much total time you have spent watching Netflix to date.
Features: Data analysis of your Netflix watch history to extract key insights
Display of your most watched series and genre, with customizable time periods (e.g. last month, last year, all-time)
Calculation of the total amount of time you have spent watching Netflix to date
Help you better understand your viewing habits

projects.name: Sorting Visualizer
projects.desc: The Sorting Visualizer is a Python project that visualizes various sorting algorithms, providing a dynamic way to better understand how these algorithms work. The project provides a user interface to select and visualize different sorting algorithms such as bubble sort, quick sort, and merge sort, and demonstrates how the algorithms sort the elements of an array in real-time
Features: Selection of different sorting algorithms for visualization, including bubble sort, quick sort, and merge sort
Customizable array size and speed of visualization
Real-time visualization of the sorting algorithm as it sorts the array elements
Dynamic color-coded visualization to help better understand the algorithm's operation

projects.name: Top Crypto Finder
projects.desc: The Top Crypto Finder is a Python project that uses web scraping techniques to find and display the top 10 cryptocurrencies in the market. The project pulls data from various cryptocurrency exchange websites, and displays key information such as the current price, market capitalization
Features: Web scraping of data from multiple cryptocurrency exchange websites to determine the top 10 cryptocurrencies
Ability to sort the coins based on various criteria, such as price, market capitalization, or trading volume

projects.name: Password Checker
projects.desc: The Password Checker is a Python project that checks the security of passwords by determining whether they have ever been a part of a data breach.
Features: Checks if the password has ever been a part of a data breach by comparing it against known lists of compromised passwords
Provides information on the severity and frequency of past data breaches, and whether the password has been found in any of them
Option to generate a random, secure password that is unlikely to be compromised

projects.name: Typo Speed Checker
projects.desc: The Typing Speed Tester is a Python project that measures your typing speed by recording the number of words you can type in a minute. The project provides a selection of different texts to type, ranging from easy to difficult, and displays the results of each test, including the number of words typed, the time taken, and the words per minute (WPM) score.
Features: Records the number of words typed, the time taken, and the WPM score
Option to practice and improve your typing speed
User-friendly interface for entering and displaying results

projects.name: Clusters
projects.desc: Clusters is a web socialzing app created with Firebase, React JS, CSS, and Bootstrap that connects university students living on campus. The app includes a chat room with options for inter-floor or inter-building conversations, short video sharing similar to TikTok, an events page for hosting events, and a Q&A forum.
Features: Chat room with options for inter-floor or inter-building conversations
Short video sharing feature similar to TikTok
Events page for hosting events and keeping track of attendees
Q&A forum for asking and answering questions related to campus life

projects.name: Long Distance Room
projects.desc: Long Distance Relationship Helper is a web-based application designed to help couples in long distance relationships stay connected and have fun together. The app features a private chat system for just the two of you, a random romantic gif generator, a movie suggestion tool, and a tracker of the days you've been in a relationship. Additionally, the app includes a random date idea generator to help spark new ideas for virtual dates.
Features: Private chat system for just you and your partner
Random romantic gif generator to send to your partner
Random movie generator to suggest a movie to watch together
Tracker of the days you've been in a relationship

projects.name: Crypto Tracker
projects.desc: Crypto Tracker is a web application that allows users to track the performance of their favorite cryptocurrencies. Users can create an account and select up to three coins that they want to monitor. The application uses chart.js to display historical price data for the selected coins, allowing users to make informed decisions about buying, selling, or holding their investments.
Features: User authentication and password recovery using Firebase Authentication
Display of historical price data using chart.js
Ability to select and track up to three cryptocurrencies
Real-time display of current price and percentage change for selected coins

projects.name: Dinosaur Google Game Player
projects.desc: Dinosaur Google Game Auto-Player is an image detection program built with Python that enables the dinosaur to run indefinitely in the popular offline Google Chrome game. The program uses the PIL module to detect obstacles and the PYTAUTOGUI module to automate key controls to make the dinosaur jump or duck to avoid obstacles.
Features: Automatically plays the Dinosaur Google Game indefinitely
Uses image detection to identify obstacles and react accordingly
Utilizes the PYTAUTOGUI module to automate key controls for the dinosaur to jump or duck

projects.name: HireLink: A Job Portal
projects.desc: The React Job Portal is a web-based platform designed specifically for recruiters to connect with job seekers. The portal allows recruiters to post job listings, filter and search resumes, and communicate with potential candidates through a messaging system. The platform is built using React, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS, which provide a seamless user experience and intuitive interface for recruiters.
Features: Recruiters can sign up and create a profile to post job listings
Job seekers can create profiles and upload resumes to be viewed by recruiters
Advanced search features allow recruiters to search for candidates by location, experience, and skills
Responsive design for seamless viewing on desktop and mobile devices
Create candidates, have job postings and apply for multiple candidates

TechnicalSkills.name: Python
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like Python because it allows me to quickly and easily write code to solve complex problems. Additionally, Python has a large and active community that provides resources and support, making it a great language for both beginners and experienced programmers.
Features: Python has a large standard library with many built-in modules and functions, making it easy to perform common programming tasks.
Python is widely used in scientific computing, data analysis, and machine learning, and has a large and supportive community.
Python has a clear and concise syntax, making it easy to read and write code.
Python is an interpreted language, meaning that you can write and execute code without needing to compile it first.

TechnicalSkills.name: Pandas
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like Pandas because it is a powerful and user-friendly tool for working with structured data in Python. It provides efficient and flexible data structures, as well as a wide range of functions for data manipulation, cleaning, and analysis. With Pandas, I can quickly and easily perform complex data operations, making it an essential library for data science and analytics.
Features: DataFrame and Series data structures, which allow for easy manipulation of tabular and time-series data.
Built-in functions for handling missing data, merging and joining data sets, and reshaping data.
Powerful grouping and aggregation functions for summarizing and analyzing data.

TechnicalSkills.name: Tableau
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like Tableau because it is a powerful data visualization tool that enables users to create interactive and visually appealing dashboards and reports. It has a wide range of data connectors, making it easy to connect to various data sources, and provides a drag-and-drop interface for creating charts and graphs.
Features: Interactive and visually appealing data visualization capabilities.
Easy-to-use drag-and-drop interface for creating charts and graphs.
Wide range of data connectors for connecting to various data sources.

TechnicalSkills.name: MATLAB
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like MATLAB because it is a powerful and widely-used tool for numerical computing and data analysis. It provides a wide range of functions and tools for working with matrices, plotting data, and analyzing complex systems. Additionally, MATLAB has a large and active community that provides resources and support, making it a great tool for both academic and industrial use.
Features: Numerical computing capabilities for working with matrices and data.
Powerful tools for data visualization and analysis.
Large and supportive community of users.

TechnicalSkills.name: HTML+CSS
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like HTML and CSS because they are the fundamental building blocks of the web. HTML provides the structure and content of web pages, while CSS provides the styling and visual design. Together, they enable web developers to create visually appealing and interactive websites that are accessible to users across a wide range of devices.
Features: HTML provides the structure and content of web pages.
CSS provides the styling and visual design of web pages.
Enables developers to create visually appealing and interactive websites.

TechnicalSkills.name: JavaScript
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like JavaScript because it is a versatile language that allows me to build interactive web applications and add functionality to websites. It is also widely used in server-side web development and can be used for desktop and mobile app development as well. With JavaScript, I can write code that runs directly in the browser, making it easy to create dynamic and responsive user interfaces.
Features: JavaScript is a scripting language that can be used in both the client-side and server-side of web development.
It is the language of the web and is supported by all major browsers.
JavaScript is a high-level language with a simple and easy-to-learn syntax.
It has a wide range of libraries and frameworks, such as React and Angular, that make it easy to build complex web applications.
JavaScript supports asynchronous programming, which allows for more efficient and responsive web applications.

TechnicalSkills.name: Java
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like Java because it is a popular and powerful programming language that can be used to develop a wide range of applications, including desktop, mobile, and web applications. It is known for its portability, security, and reliability.
Features: Java is an object-oriented language with a strong type system that makes it easy to write and maintain complex code.
It is platform-independent, meaning that code written on one platform can be run on any other platform that supports Java.
Java is used extensively in enterprise applications, such as banking, insurance, and healthcare, due to its scalability, security, and reliability.

TechnicalSkills.name: React
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like React because it is a powerful and flexible JavaScript library that allows me to build complex and interactive user interfaces with ease. It follows a component-based architecture that makes it easy to reuse code and separate concerns, leading to more maintainable and scalable code. With React, I can write reusable UI components that can be shared across different applications, making development faster and more efficient.
Features: React uses a virtual DOM, which makes it fast and efficient for rendering large and complex UIs.
It follows a declarative programming paradigm, which makes it easier to reason about and debug code.
React provides a wide range of lifecycle methods and hooks that allow for more granular control over component behavior.
It has a vast ecosystem of third-party libraries and tools, such as Redux and Next.js, that make development faster and more efficient.
React is used by many large companies, such as Facebook and Airbnb, and has a large and active community that provides resources, support, and updates to the library.
It is highly flexible and can be used with other technologies, such as server-side rendering and native mobile development, using tools like React Native.

TechnicalSkills.name: Git / GitHub
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like Git and GitHub because they are powerful and widely used tools for version control, collaboration, and project management. Git is a distributed version control system that allows me to easily track changes to my code and collaborate with others. GitHub is a web-based platform that provides hosting for Git repositories, as well as a wide range of features for project management, code review, and collaboration.
Features: Distributed version control system with support for branching, merging, and versioning.
Collaboration and project management features, such as pull requests, issues, and milestones.
Web-based platform for hosting repositories, with tools for code review, continuous integration, and deployment.

TechnicalSkills.name: JIRA / CONFLUENCE
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like JIRA and Confluence because they are powerful and versatile tools that allow me to manage projects, collaborate with team members, and track progress in a streamlined and efficient way. JIRA is a project management tool that allows me to create and track tasks, issues, and bugs in a highly customizable way. Confluence, on the other hand, is a knowledge management tool that allows me to create and organize documentation, meeting notes, and other important information in a central location that can be easily accessed by team members.
Features: JIRA provides a highly customizable workflow that can be tailored to the specific needs of a project or team.
JIRA allows for easy collaboration between team members, with features such as commenting, tagging, and notifications.
Confluence allows for easy creation and organization of documentation, with features such as templates, macros, and versioning.
Confluence provides a robust search function that allows team members to quickly find the information they need.
JIRA and Confluence can be easily integrated with other tools and services, such as GitHub and Slack, through plugins and APIs.
Both JIRA and Confluence are widely used in the software development industry and have large and active communities that provide resources and support.

TechnicalSkills.name: R Programming
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like R programming because it is a powerful and versatile language for statistical computing, data analysis, and visualization. R has a wide range of built-in functions and packages that allow me to perform complex statistical analyses and create informative visualizations with ease. With R, I can also easily manipulate and clean data, making it an essential tool for data science and research.
Features: A wide range of built-in functions and packages for statistical computing, data analysis, and visualization.
R allows for easy manipulation and cleaning of data, with functions such as subsetting, filtering, and reshaping.
R provides powerful graphics and visualization capabilities, with packages such as ggplot2 and lattice.
R is widely used in academic research and industry, particularly in the fields of statistics, data science, and machine learning.

TechnicalSkills.name: Postman API
TechnicalSkills.desc: I like Postman API because it is a powerful and user-friendly tool for testing and documenting APIs. With Postman, I can easily create and manage API requests, as well as automate testing and generate documentation. Additionally, Postman has a large and supportive community, with a wide range of resources and integrations.
Features: Powerful and flexible API request builder, with support for various HTTP methods, parameters, and authentication methods.
Automated testing capabilities, including test scripts, assertions, and collection runners.
Documentation generation tools, including automatic documentation based on API requests and custom templates.

Work.name: QA Intern
desc: Collaborate with teams to design test plans and scripts for web and mobile applications
Utilize tools like JSON, Postman, JIRA, TestRail, and CI/CD for defect tracking and test automation.
Develop comprehensive test suites with QA to ensure thorough product testing.
Work closely with developers and product owners to efficiently resolve defects.

Work.name: VR Research Intern
desc: Manage Creating an immersive environment for people so that they can feel and visualize different aspects of storytelling via VR
Working in a 3d workspace with hands-on experience with the development of an upcoming story-based project
Help solve issues and troubleshoot various hardware and software problems.
Recording and storing live movement onto a 3d figure

Work.name: Web Developer
desc: Secured a part-time job at the University of Victoria through strong academic knowledge and innovative thinking. Delivers commercial websites that meet coding standards and ensures cross-browser compatibility. Streamlined WordPress development with reusable code libraries. Experienced in recording and storing live movements onto 3D figures.

Courses.name: Datastructures and Algorithms - 2
Courses.desc: Advanced techniques for design, analysis, and implementation of algorithms and data structures.Algorithmic design paradigms: greedy, divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, randomization.Advanced Analysis techniques: amortization and expected running time.Advanced data structures: random hash families, disjoint sets.Advanced graph algorithms: network flow, connectivity, minimum spanning trees, shortest paths. Mathematical tools: graphs and digraphs, graph properties, planar graphs, networks.String search. Data compression

Courses.name: Introduction to Computer Architecture
Courses.desc: the design of processors,the structure and operation of memory and virtual memory, cache, storage,pipelining + system integration + peripherals.Execution of software via assembly language

Courses.name: Software Development Methods
Courses.desc: Systematic methods for designing, coding, testing and documenting medium-sized programs. Tools and techniques to promote programming productivity and software quality. Topics include specifications, code review and inspection techniques, testing and debugging methods and tools, file system navigation, scripting languages, software tools, environments, instrumenting and profiling and the fundamentals of software configuration management.

Courses.name: World Wide Web and Mobile Applications
Courses.desc: An introduction to the Internet, the World Wide Web (WWW) and mobile communications technologies. Topics include: HTML; web-page design tools; development of simple mobile applications. Additional topics selected from: location-aware e-commerce; multimedia chat services; mobile social networking; software development for smartphones and tablets. Emphasis is on relating Internet technologies to the role they play in enabling mobile computing.

Courses.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics
Courses.desc: descriptive statistics; elementary probability theory; random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, expectation, joint, marginal and conditional distributions; linear functions of random variables; random sampling and sampling distributions; point and interval estimation; classical hypothesis testing and significance testing. The mathematical foundations of statistical inference are introduced and illustrated with examples from a variety of disciplines.

Courses.name: Matrix Algebra
Courses.desc: Euclidean vector spaces; systems of linear equations, solution of linear systems by Gaussian elimination, matrices and matrix algebra; brief introduction to abstract vector space; determinants; eigenvectors; orthogonality and applications.

Courses.name: Fundamental Programing II
Courses.desc: Techniques, methods, and tools for systematic development and maintenance of software systems and documentation; basic algorithms and data structures; and fundamental concepts of object-oriented programming. Topics include control and data abstraction, modularization, abstract data types, layers of abstraction, information hiding, separation of concerns, type checking, program design, separate compilation, software libraries, techniques for the development of high-quality software components, program understanding.

Courses.name: Fundamental Programming I
Courses.desc: Introduction to designing, implementing, and understanding computer programs using an object-oriented programming language. Topics include an introduction to computing and problem solving, selection and iteration, arrays and collections, objects and classes, top-down design and incremental development.

Courses.name: Discrete Math - Logic and Foundations
Courses.desc: Logic and quantifiers, basic set theory, mathematical induction and recursive definitions, divide and conquer recurrence relations, properties of integers, counting, functions and relations, countable and uncountable sets, asymptotic notation
